title: Designing Data-Intensive Applications
author: Martin Kleppmann
thoughts: The bible of distributed systems. Every chapter made me rethink something I thought I understood. The section on consistency models alone is worth the price.

title: The Staff Engineer's Path
author: Tanya Reilly
thoughts: Halfway through. Already changed how I think about influence vs authority. The 'being glue' framing hit hard.

title: Project Hail Mary
author: Andy Weir
thoughts: Read it in two sittings. The friendship at the center of this book is one of the best I've encountered in sci-fi. Funny, tense, genuinely moving.

title: A Philosophy of Software Design
author: John Ousterhout
thoughts: Short, opinionated, useful. 'Complexity is incremental' should be tattooed on every codebase. Disagree with some of the deep module takes but the core ideas are solid.

title: The Pragmatic Programmer
author: Hunt & Thomas
thoughts: Re-read the 20th anniversary edition. Some advice feels obvious now â€” which probably means it shaped how I think without me noticing.

title: Klara and the Sun
author: Kazuo Ishiguro
thoughts: Quietly devastating. Ishiguro writes AI with more empathy than most people write humans. The unreliable narration through Klara's limited understanding is masterful.

title: The Phoenix Project
author: Kim, Behr & Spafford
thoughts: Good ideas wrapped in mediocre fiction. If you've lived through a bad deployment pipeline, you'll recognize every character. The DevOps principles land even if the prose doesn't.

title: Exhalation
author: Ted Chiang
thoughts: Every story is a thought experiment that refuses to stay abstract. 'The Lifecycle of Software Objects' is the most honest thing written about AI relationships.

title: System Design Interview
author: Alex Xu
thoughts: Useful as a reference, not great as a read. Good for pattern recognition before interviews. Wouldn't revisit.

title: The Three-Body Problem
author: Cixin Liu
thoughts: The scale of imagination here is unmatched. The Dark Forest theory changed how I think about the Fermi paradox. Characters are thin but the ideas are enormous.

title: Thinking, Fast and Slow
author: Daniel Kahneman
thoughts: Got through about 60%. Fascinating material but the repetition wore me down. The anchoring and framing chapters were excellent. Will probably finish someday.

title: Atomic Habits
author: James Clear
thoughts: Could have been a blog post. But the blog post would have been really good. The habit stacking idea stuck with me more than I expected.
